metadata.case_name: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt

facts.text: Shirur Math is one of eight Maths at Udipi founded by Madhwacharya, presided by Sanyasi or Swami; another institution Shri Krishna Devara Math managed by superiors of eight Maths in turns for two years every sixteen years with Pariyayam festival.

Respondent installed as Mathadhipati in 1919 as minor, assumed management in 1926; Math in debt, cleared portion by 1930; in 1931 took over Shri Krishna Math, incurred debts for Pariyayam; troubles in 1946 second Pariyayam due to scarcity, debts to nearly one lakh rupees.
Hindu Religious Endowments Board under 1927 Act intervened in 1946, directed appointment of competent manager under s.61A.
Respondent alleges Board action instigated by Lakshminarayana Rao; Sripath Achar appointed agent, Power of Attorney on 24 Dec 1948; agent disregarded Mathadhipati's wishes, did not submit accounts.
Respondent served notice terminating agency on 26 Sep 1950, demanding accounts and cash.
Agent questioned termination, threatened Board reference; respondent filed suit on 4 Oct 1950 in Sub-Court South Kanara for accounts, injunction.
Agent filed application to Board on 3 Oct 1950 complaining cancellation; Board issued notice 4 Oct 1950 for enquiry 24 Oct; respondent replied 21 Oct sub-judice, sent plaint.
Board dropped enquiry, initiated suo motu under s.62 on 6 Nov 1950, notice for scheme enquiry 8 Dec 1950 served by affixture.
Enquiry adjourned to 21 Dec at counsel request; application for agent handover; further adjourned to 10 Jan 1951 due to counsel illness; no objections filed, enquiry closed.
Written explanation sent 13 Jan 1951, received 15 Jan; notice 24 Jan 1951 with draft scheme, objections by 11 Feb, final order 15 Feb.
Petition filed 12 Feb 1951 in Madras HC under Art 226 for writ of prohibition alleging bias, unconstitutionality vs Arts 19(1)(f),26,15.
New Act 1951 came into force 27 Aug 1951, petition amended; Commissioner added under s.103.
HC by Division Bench 13 Dec 1951 allowed petition, issued writ prohibiting scheme; held Board action perverse, several New Act sections ultra vires Arts 19(1)(f),25,26,27.
Appeal to SC with certificate under Art 132(1).

legal_issues.text: Whether Mathadhipati has property rights under Art 19(1)(f) in Math endowments, and if Act provisions unreasonably restrict them.
Whether provisions affect right under Art 25 to practise and propagate religion.
Whether Shirur Math constitutes religious denomination under Art 26, and if Act interferes with management in matters of religion.
Whether s.76 contribution is tax beyond state competence or violates Art 27.
Validity of specific New Act sections: 18,20,21,23-31,52-59,63-70,76,89,99 etc. re Maths.

petitioner_arguments.text: Art 19(1)(f) concerns abstract right to property, not concrete rights; no application to Mathadhipati.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose

petitioner_arguments.text: Art 25 protects individuals only, not institutions; propagation by Mathadhipati not protected.
Math not religious denomination under Art 26; clause (b) limited to strict matters of religion, excluding secular activities.
s.76 is fee for services, not tax; within state competence under List III entry 28, fee under entry 47.
Provisions reasonable regulation of secular administration, not interfering with religious matters.

respondent_arguments.text: Board action biased, instigated by Lakshminarayana Rao, perverse exercise of jurisdiction.
Act provisions conflict with fundamental rights under Arts 19(1)(f), 25, 26, 15; discriminatory.
Mathadhipati has proprietary interest in endowments; restrictions unreasonable.
Shirur Math for Sivalli Brahmins, section of Madhwacharya followers, religious denomination.

court_reasoning.text: Mathadhipati holds beneficial interest akin to Shebait, blending office and property; protected under Art 19(1)(f); restrictions reasonable if not reducing to servant level.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mahant has personal beneficial interest sanctioned by custom.

court_reasoning.text: Art 25 protects individuals including Mathadhipati as religious teacher; propagation of doctrines protected.
Math constitutes religious denomination or section thereof under Art 26; autonomy in religious matters, but property administration regulable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Religion includes beliefs, rituals, observances; essential parts determined by doctrines.

court_reasoning.text: s.76 is fee for services (quasi quid pro quo), not tax; within state competence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fee based on services rendered by govt officers.

court_reasoning.text: Invalidated sections: 21 (unrestricted entry), 30(2),31 (restrictions on surplus),55(1)(2) (pathakanikas),56 (manager appointment), Ch VI 63-69 (notification), others upheld like 20,23-29,54,58,59,70,76,89,99.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions infringing religious practice or unreasonable on property rights invalid.

holdings.text: Mathadhipati's rights include property interest under Art 19(1)(f); unreasonable restrictions invalid.
Art 25 applies to Mathadhipati's propagation; protected unless secular activity.
Shirur Math religious denomination under Art 26; management in religious matters autonomous.
s.76 valid as fee, not tax; no violation of Art 27.
Specific sections ultra vires re Maths: 21,30(2),31,55(1)(2),56,63-69; others valid.

precedents_cited.relevance: Mahant not mere trustee but manager with beneficial interest.
Blends office and property in Shebait/Mahantship.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose
precedents_cited.relevance: Art 19(1)(f) on abstract vs concrete property rights (not decided).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental rights protection; legislative competence; invalidity test.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1927 (Act II of 1927)
Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged provisions on administration, schemes, contributions; some held invalid for Maths.

outcome.summary: High Court writ of prohibition upheld on merits (not challenged); on constitutional issues, Supreme Court upheld invalidity of some sections (21,30(2),31,55(1)(2),56,63-69) but validated others including s.76 as fee; prohibited further scheme proceedings.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ of prohibition against scheme settlement; certain Act sections declared ultra vires re Maths.

key_quotes.text: In the conception of Mahantship, as in Shebaitship, both the elements of office and property, of duties and personal interest are blended together and neither can be detached from the other.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines nature of Mathadhipati's rights under Art 19(1)(f).

key_quotes.text: What constitutes the essential part of a religion is primarily to be ascertained with reference to the doctrines of that religion itself.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Delineates scope of 'matters of religion' under Art 26(b).

key_quotes.text: A fee is generally defined to be a charge for a special service rendered to individuals by some governmental agency.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes fee from tax for s.76 validity.
